Music by the Second Army
Dance Band will be featured at the
Military Ball to be held tomorrow
night from 9 to 1 at the Gym.
The dance is sponsored by the
National Society of Pershing Rifles
and the National Society of Scabbard and Blade and is open to the
entire campus. Dress will be forMai; ROTC cadets may wear their
uniforms.
Campus-Wide
"We are aiming at making this
the most
outstanding campusWide dance of the year," Bill
Hoover, dance committee chairMan, said recently.
"We are decorating the Gym,
giving favors and programs, and
Providing continuous music. This
Is the year's biggest dance value,"
said Hoover.
Hoover also explained that plans
to give flowers have fallen through,
due to the impossibility'af getting
good flowers at a low enough price.
Cotillion
Feature of the evening will be
the commander's cotillion. At that
time the date of the cadet colonel,
the dates
of the captains of the
aDonsoring organizations, and the
Cadet company commanders will be
Presented and given bouquets.
Various dance sets will be used,
each containing a central theme.
Some of these are "Popular Favorites" and "In Old Vienna" and
"South of the Border."
Set-ups will be sold. Invitations
Will be available at the door only
if the dance is not sold out before
tomorrow night. Hoover stated
that the possibility of a sell-out
Was great, judging by ticket sales

Orientation Week
Chairman Sought

Student Council President Alan
Birtch this week appealed to the
student body for applications for
Orientation Week Chairman.
The deadline for applications Is
March 24.
"Anyone who feels at all qualified is urged to turn in their
name," Birtch said. The only qualification is that the person has had
previous orientation exper:ence.
The Orientation Chairman and
Dr. W. Kelso Morrill, Diiector of
Student Activities will set up the
entire Orientation program. The
Chairman also has complete charge
of picking group leaders and other
workers.
To apply, the student should
send a letter giving his name, post
office box number, and qualifications to the Student Council, Post
Office Box 1246.
The council will interview applicants on March 29 and select
chairman on April 5.
Don Peyser was Orientation
Week Chairman last year.

A Specialty

What do YOU look for in an employer?
Undoubtedly, you'll want most of the following characteristics:
1. Job satisfaction—the chance to do work you really enjoy.
2.Recognition—the assurance that good work will be noticed, appreciated,
and properly rewarded.
3. Opportunities for advancement—a growing company can provide them.
4.Security—the knowledge that a company is both stable and progressive.
5.Pride—a feeling that your company is respected by the public and produces
goods which contribute to a better way of life.
6. Good companionship—a factor which contributes greatly to happiness on
the job.
7.Good pay—not in salary alone, but also in terms of vacation plans,pensions,
and other benefits.
8.Safe working conditions.
How can you obtain this kind of information in advance?
One of the best ways is to discuss the matter with an acquaintance already
working for the company you are considering. You will also find it helpful to
consult your college placement officer, your professors and company representatives visiting your campus.
The selection of an employer ig one of the most important decisions you'll
make. It justifies considerable thought and effort.

Strider, Students
Discuss Parking
Suggestions made last week by
dormitory students for the improvement of on-campus parking
at the dorm will be forwarded to
the faculty committee on parking,
Mr. Robert Strider, Assistant Plant
Manager, announced this week.
The ideas were discussed by
Strider and a dorm committee composed of Al Webb and James Robinson at a recent meeting. No
definate conclusions were made,
pending the findings of the faculty
committee.

The Goofballs won the independent bowling title and Alpha
Epsilon Pi took top honors among
the fraternities in the Board of
Intramural Athletics bowling finale
of the winter season.
The Goofballs, including Murphy, Sutera, Hahn, McDonough,
Panuska, and Martin, capped their
18-3 seven-week season record as
Hahn gained 368 pins in one afternoon. Panuska rolled the high
game of the season, with a 148.
For the fraternity team, Vic
Marder copped 353 pins for the
afternoon and took top honors
with 1,482 pins. Delta Upsilon
came in a close second with a
total of 1,477 pins. Tom Kelm led
D. U. with a high 142 game in
the second set.

Orientation Week
Chairman Sought

Student Council President Alan
Birtch this week appealed to the
student body for applications for
Orientation Week Chairman.
The deadline for applications Is
March 24.
"Anyone who feels at all qualified is urged to turn in their
name," Birtch said. The only qualification is that the person has had
previous orientation exper:ence.
The Orientation Chairman and
Dr. W. Kelso Morrill, Diiector of
Student Activities will set up the
entire Orientation program. The
Chairman also has complete charge
of picking group leaders and other
workers.
To apply, the student should
send a letter giving his name, post
office box number, and qualifications to the Student Council, Post
Office Box 1246.
The council will interview applicants on March 29 and select
chairman on April 5.
Don Peyser was Orientation
Week Chairman last year.

What do YOU look for in an employer?
Undoubtedly, you'll want most of the following characteristics:
1. Job satisfaction—the chance to do work you really enjoy.
2.Recognition—the assurance that good work will be noticed, appreciated,
and properly rewarded.
3. Opportunities for advancement—a growing company can provide them.
4.Security—the knowledge that a company is both stable and progressive.
5.Pride—a feeling that your company is respected by the public and produces
goods which contribute to a better way of life.
6. Good companionship—a factor which contributes greatly to happiness on
the job.
7.Good pay—not in salary alone, but also in terms of vacation plans,pensions,
and other benefits.
8.Safe working conditions.
How can you obtain this kind of information in advance?
One of the best ways is to discuss the matter with an acquaintance already
working for the company you are considering. You will also find it helpful to
consult your college placement officer, your professors and company representatives visiting your campus.
The selection of an employer ig one of the most important decisions you'll
make. It justifies considerable thought and effort.
